key_insight: Closing the information gap between privileged expert demonstrations and sensor-limited student observations — by intentionally reducing expert advantages (visibility/uncertainty) or making demonstrations learner-aware — substantially improves closed-loop imitation driving performance in simulation.
problem_solved: Imitation-learned end-to-end driving policies trained on privileged expert data fail in closed-loop because experts have higher visibility and lower uncertainty than the sensor-based learners; this paper addresses that learner–expert asymmetry.
method: Quantify the asymmetry between privileged expert state (full visibility, low uncertainty) and student sensor observations.
Reduce expert advantages via interventions (e.g., masking privileged info, adding occlusions/noise, or generating learner-aware expert targets) so demonstrations match student perceptual limitations.
Evaluate the impact of asymmetry reduction on closed-loop robustness and driving metrics in simulated scenarios.
impact: By aligning expert demonstrations with what sensor-based learners actually perceive, practitioners can train more robust, realistic imitation policies in simulation that transfer better to closed-loop driving tasks.
visual_elements: Side-by-side diagram: privileged expert view (full scene) vs. student sensor view (occlusions, limited FOV) highlighting missing information.
Before/after trajectory overlay showing failure modes with asymmetric experts and improved trajectories after asymmetry reduction.
Bar chart of closed-loop performance metrics (collision rate, lane-keeping, success rate) comparing baseline vs. LEAD interventions.
Flowchart of the training pipeline: expert data → asymmetry reduction (mask/noise/learner-aware) → student policy training → closed-loop evaluation
paper_title: LEAD: Minimizing Learner-Expert Asymmetry in End-to-End Driving
paper_authors: Long Nguyen, Micha Fauth, Bernhard Jaeger, Daniel Dauner, Maximilian Igl
